boat.name: Nightingale
boat.full_description:
Nightingale was launched in 1996 by an East Coast Bargemaster and was in service until July 2000. She was subsequently sold and equipped by her new owners for offshore cruising.

Nightingale replicates the heavy displacement cruising yachts designed by William Atkin in 1925 to meet the demand in the USA created by Ralph Stock's book 'The Cruise of the Dream Ship' describing how, in 1918, Ralph Stock bought a Swedish built Colin Archer pilot boat, built at the turn of the century. He sailed with his sister and a friend to the Pacific Islands via the Panama Canal, in order to recuperate from the horrors of the First World War.
boat.short_description: A Colin Archer type, built in 1980, Nightingale changed hands three times before completion.

for_sales.sales_text:
33”, 4 berth Gaff Cutter.

For the last 20 years Nightingale has visited most of the Traditional Boat Festivals throughout northern Europe. This magnificent sea boat has looked after her present owners for over 20 years, providing a fulfilling and enjoyable retirement. Unfortunately, it is now time to ask someone else to plan her summer cruising programme and look after her. Professionally-built in 1980, Nightingale’s mono-coque, ferro-cement hull and decks have been uniquely sheathed and encapsulated in epoxy resin in order to provide the driest and most comfortable traditionally rigged boat imaginable. The four large berths, plus a pilot berth, enable four adults to make distance passages in comfort. Fitted with a 25 hp, 3 cylinder Vetus/Mitsubishi engine and 250 litre fuel tank for long-distance cruising. All electronic equipment is in full working order, including the fully-integrated trim-tab steering system with numerous spares. Comprehensive sail wardrobe for both cruising and racing, plus many extras including life raft, rigid and inflatable dinghy if required.

Lying Cowes, Isle of Wight.
